content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Georgia Tech Conferences</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/7435" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle>Conferences sponsored or hosted by Georgia Tech </subtitle> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/7435</id> <updated>2015-03-06T08:14:53Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-06T08:14:53Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Society of Engineering Science, 49th Annual Technical Meeting: Abstracts</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53206" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name/> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53206</id> <updated>2015-03-05T08:31:05Z</updated> <published>2012-10-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Society of Engineering Science, 49th Annual Technical Meeting: Abstracts The 49th Annual Technical Meeting of the Society of Engineering Science was held in Atlanta, GA, October 10-12, 2012. Over three days, several hundred leading researchers in the engineering sciences from around the world met to exchange ideas and progress in research, to discuss the interfaces between engineering, sciences and mathematics, and to discuss the balance between emerging and established fields. This document collects the submitted abstracts for presentation at the meeting. </summary> <dc:date>2012-10-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:description>The 49th Annual Technical Meeting of the Society of Engineering Science was held in Atlanta, GA, October 10-12, 2012. Over three days, several hundred leading researchers in the engineering sciences from around the world met to exchange ideas and progress in research, to discuss the interfaces between engineering, sciences and mathematics, and to discuss the balance between emerging and established fields. This document collects the submitted abstracts for presentation at the meeting.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>Using Participatory Management in Access Services Improves Staff Quality and Participation in Decision-Making</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53131" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Morrison, Ray L.</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53131</id> <updated>2015-01-15T08:35:35Z</updated> <published>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Using Participatory Management in Access Services Improves Staff Quality and Participation in Decision-Making Morrison, Ray L. Access Services Librarians are now beginning to use participatory management to successfully direct their staff. Using participatory management increases work productivity, greater job satisfaction, higher level of motivation, improved quality and reduced costs. The speaker is an advocate of participatory management and has used it as a Library Director for over two decades and now as the Coordinator of Access Services. Presented at the 2014 Access Services Conference, November 12-14, 2014, Georgia Tech Global Learning Center and the Georgia Tech Hotel and Conference Center, Atlanta, Georgia. </summary> <dc:date>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Morrison, Ray L.</dc:creator> <dc:description>Access Services Librarians are now beginning to use participatory management to successfully direct their staff. Using participatory management increases work productivity, greater job satisfaction, higher level of motivation, improved quality and reduced costs. The speaker is an advocate of participatory management and has used it as a Library Director for over two decades and now as the Coordinator of Access Services.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>Student Library Use Data and Class Standing</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53130" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Sneed, Thomas</name> </author> <author> <name>Walsh, Felicity</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53130</id> <updated>2015-01-15T08:35:33Z</updated> <published>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Student Library Use Data and Class Standing Sneed, Thomas; Walsh, Felicity Budgets are tight at academic institutions everywhere and this can affect library budgets.  This year, MacMillan Library had harvested and combined data on student GPAs, library circulation data and gate entrance data to see if there is any correlation between library use and student success. Presented at the 2014 Access Services Conference, November 12-14, 2014, Georgia Tech Global Learning Center and the Georgia Tech Hotel and Conference Center, Atlanta, Georgia. </summary> <dc:date>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Sneed, Thomas</dc:creator> <dc:creator>Walsh, Felicity</dc:creator> <dc:description>Budgets are tight at academic institutions everywhere and this can affect library budgets.  This year, MacMillan Library had harvested and combined data on student GPAs, library circulation data and gate entrance data to see if there is any correlation between library use and student success.</dc:description> </entry> <entry> <title>Be Our Guest - Exceptional Patron Library Experience</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53129" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Sotilleo, Sophia</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/53129</id> <updated>2015-01-15T08:35:35Z</updated> <published>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Be Our Guest - Exceptional Patron Library Experience Sotilleo, Sophia The Be Our Guest program is a session where we will discuss and outline proven principles and processes that will help focus your library vision and assemble your team to enhance and deliver exceptional customer service. If Disney can do it why can\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt we? Presented at the 2014 Access Services Conference, November 12-14, 2014, Georgia Tech Global Learning Center and the Georgia Tech Hotel and Conference Center, Atlanta, Georgia. </summary> <dc:date>2014-11-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>Sotilleo, Sophia</dc:creator> <dc:description>The Be Our Guest program is a session where we will discuss and outline proven principles and processes that will help focus your library vision and assemble your team to enhance and deliver exceptional customer service. If Disney can do it why can\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt we?</dc:description> </entry> </feed>
